bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington

org.orgName: United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AND FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Plaintiff, vs. YO YOU JAM, Defendant.} No. 3395 PETITION

Comes now JOHN J. SULLIVAN, as attorney for and in behalf of Yo You Jam, an alleged citizen of the United States and an alleged son of Yo Bing Goe, a citizen of the United States and resident of New York City, New York, and respectfully makes this application for a Writ of Habeas Corpus and alleges as follows:

That Yo You Jam is imprisoned and restrained of his liberty by the United States Commissioner of Immigration, Henry M. White, and the United States Chinese Inspector, Henry Monroe, or by person or persons acting by, through or under them, and that said Yo You Jam has been detained at the Detention office the Immigration Station inn the City of Seattle, under the charge that the said Yo You Jam has no lawful right to be admitted into the United States, and that he should be deported according to law.

And your petitioner further informs the Honorable Court that saud imprisonment, confinement and restraint and Order of Deportation is illegal, and arises from the following facts, to wit: That said Yo You Jam arrived at the port of Seattle on a voyage from China on the steamship "Ixion" on May 4, 1916; that said Yo You Jam was given a hearing and was denied admittance into the United States on the ground that he was not legally entitled to be admitted therein; that an appeal was given by the said Yo You Jam, through his attorney, James V. Storey of New York City, to the
Secretary of Labor, and that on July 24, 1916, the said Order of Deportation and said Finding of Commissioner of Immigration of Seattle, Washington, was affirmed and said Yo You Jam was ordered deported.

Your peritioner further alleges that said Order on Appeal and said Order of Deportation is null and void, and that the said Yo You Jam has been denied the right to have his appeal heard by the Secretary of Labor, as by statute made and provided in such cases; that your petitioner has not had a fair hearing, in that it appears in the record that the petitioner was entitled to be admitted into the United States under the law and the Constitution of the United States, and to deny him admission was a deprivation of his constitutional rights.

Your petitioner further alleges that said hearing given by the Immigration officials on appeal was unfair, and that said officials were arbitrary and abused the powers given them under the law, and that by reason thereof, your said petitioner has been denied his rights allowed by law and by the Constitution of the United States.

Your petitioner further alleges that he has not had a fair trial in that letters, merorandums, etc., from officials and inspectors, of the Department were considered by the Commissioner of Immigration and by the Secretary of Labor, or his assistants, without the petitioner beign given a right to deny the same, or being apprised of their contents; that the same were not given under oath, and were not evidence, being hearsay, and not permissible under the rules governing the admission of Chinese, and that the receiving of the same by the said officials was a ursurpation of their power and a violation of the rights of your petitioner under the law; that the father of your petitioner Yo Bing Goe has been adjudicated to be an American citizen and that your petitioner as the son of said Yo Bing Goe is an American citizen himself, and being so has the
right of entry into the united States as an American citizen, and that the evidence presented by said Yo You Jam presents a prima facie case and a proof of his citizenship; that the United States Immigration officials have not offered any proof to contradict said showing of citizenship, and that, therefore, the denial of the right of entry of your petitioner deprives him of his constitutional rights and is contrary to law.

Your petitioner further alleges that the entire record, which your petitioner asks to be made a part of this petitition or Writ of Habeas Corpus, discloses such irregularity and illegality that this Honorable Court should investigate the record to do justice to an American citizen.

Your petitioner further states that he has deposited the sum of One Hundred ($100.00) Dollars with the Commissioner of Immigration to pay for his board and lodging pending the final determination of this case.
Your petitioner prays that he be allowed to go forth on bail fixed by this Honorable Court, pending the final determination of this case adjudicating his rights.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that his Court find that he has not been accorded the rights and privileges allowed by the Constitution of the united States and by the Chinese Exclusion Laws and rules and regulations pertaining thereto, and that he be discharged and allowed to join his father who is a citizen of the United States living in New York City.
Dated this 4th day of August, 1916. By Yo You Jam John Sullivan Attorney for Petitioner
